div.p:
But the beads I had given
to my principal men
were only sufficient
for a scanty meal and
49 I had hastened on to
this village in order to
slaughter an ox a tired
ox and give them all
a good feed a feast
and rest on Sunday
as a preparation for
the journey in front
I explained this to them
and thought their grumbling
was allayed - and soon
sank into a state of
stupor which the fever
sometimes caused produced
and was oblivious
to all their noise in
slaughtering - On Sunday
the mutineers were
making a terrible noise
in preparing some skins
they had procured
I requested them twice
by the man who attended
me to be more quiet
as the noise pained
me - But as they paid
no attention to this
civil request I put out
my head and repeating
it myself was answered
455
by an impudent laugh - Knowing
that discipline would
be at an end if this
mutiny were not quelled
I seized a double barrelled
pistol and darted forth
50 from the domicile looking
I suppose such daggers
as to put them to
a precipitate flight - As
some remained within
hearing I told them that
I must maintain discipline
though at the expense
of some of their
limbs - So long as we
travelled together they
must remem-berremember that
I and not they wereas
masters - They became
very obediaent immediately
and never afterwards
gave any trouble or
imagined that they
had any right in any
of my property I poss

Cross 13 - We went forward some
miles but were brought
to a stand by the severity
of my fever on the
banks of ^ a branch of of the Loajima another
tributary of the CasaiKasai
I was in a state of partial
coma untilluntil late at night
456
when it became necessary
for me to go out and
was surprised to find
that my men had built
a little stockade and
51 some of them took their
spears and acted as
a gaurdguard - I found that
we were surrounded
by by enemies and a
party of Chiboque lay
near the gateway
after having preferred
athe demand of "a man
an ox or a gun" - or a
tusk" - My men had
prepared for defence in
case of a night attack
and when the Chiboque
wished to be shewnshown
where I lay sick my
men very properly
refused - In the morning
I went out to the Chiboque
and found that they answered
me civilly regarding my
intentions in opening
the country teaching them
& - & - that their chiefs
would be pleased with
the prospect of opening
the country and now
only wished to exchange
tokens of good will with me
457
and presented three pigs which
they hoped I would accept
three pigs - As they are
in the habit of making
a present in this part
of the country and then
52 demanding whatever
they may like in return
and we had been fore-
warned of it by our
guides I tried to decline
by asking if they would
eat one of the pigs
in company with us.
To this proposition
they said they durst not
accede - I then accepted
them in the hope that
the blame of deficient
in friendly feeling should
not rest with me -
and presented a razor
two bunches of beads and
twelve copper rings con-
tributed by my men
from their arms. They
went off to report to
their chief and as I was
quite unable to move
from excessive giddiness
we were in the same
spot on tuesdayTuesday evening
when they returned with
a message couched
in very plain terms
458
that a man, tusk gun or even ox
alone would be acceptable
that he had every thing else
in his possession but
53 oxen and that whatever
I should please to demand
from him he would gladly
give it - As this was all
said civilly and there
was no help for it if
we refused but bloodshed
I gave a tired riding ox
My chief mutineer an
AmbondAmbonda man was
now over loyal for he
armed himself and
stood at the gateway
He would rather die than
see his father imposed
on - but I ordered Mosantu
to take him out of the
way and he did it
promptly and allowed
the Chiboque to march
off well pleased with
their booty - I told my
men that I esteemed
one of their lives more
than all the oxen we
had and it would only
be to save the lives &
liberties of the majority
that would induce me
to fight - In the propriety
of this they all agreed - and
459
said that if the Chiboque molested
us who behaved so peaceably
the guilt would be theirs
This is a favourite mode
54 of expression throughout
the whole country All are
anxious to give explanation
of any acts they have
performed and conclude
the narration Iwith - "I have
no guilt or blame" (- "molatu")
"They or he hasve the guilt" - I never
could be positive whether the
idea in their minds is guilt
in the sight of the Deity or
mankind only -

Thornborough Next morning the robber
party came with about
thirty yards of strong striped
English calico, an axe
and two hoes for our
acceptance - and returned
the copper rings as the
chief was a great man
and did not need the
ornaments of my men
but we noticed that
they were taken back again -
I divided the cloth among
ourmy men and pleased
them a little in lieu of
the loss of the ox - I advised
the chief whose name
we did not learn as he
460
did not deign to appear except
Matiamvo under the alias Matiamvo
to get cattle for his own
use and expressed sorrow
that I had none wherewith
to enable him ^ to make a commencement
with - Rains prevented our
55 proceeding ontill Thursday and
on morning and their
messenger appeared to tell
us that their chief had
learned that all the cloth
had not been presented
and the copper rings
secreted by persons
sent to us previously
and he had stripped him
them of their property as
a punishment - Our
guides thought these were
only spies of a larger
party secreted in the
forest through which
we were now to pass
We prepared for defence
by marching in a
compact body and
allowing no one to
straggle far behind the
others - We marched through
many miles of gloomy
forest in gloomier
silence but nothing
disturbed us - We came
to a village and found
461
all the men absent - the
guides thought in the
forest with their country-
-men - I was too ill to
care much whether we
were attacked or not
56 but a pouring rain came
on and as we were
all anxious to get away
out of a bad neighbourhood
we went on - The thick
atmosphere prevented my
seeing the creeping plants
in time to duck under
them so I was Pitsane
Mohorisi and I who ^ alone were
mounted were often caught
and as there is no stopping
of the oxen when they have
the prospect of givegiving
the rider a tumble we
came frequently to the
ground - In addition
to these mishaps Sinbad
went off at a plunging
gallop the bridle broke
and I came down
backwards on the crown
of my head - He gave me
a kick on the thigh at the
same time - I was ^ felt none
the worse for this rough
treatment but would not
recommend it to to others
in cases of fever!
462
This last attack of fever was
so obstinate it reduced me
almost to a skeleton - The blanket
which was used as a saddle
on the back of the ox
being frequently wet remained
57 wet in the hot sun &
aided by the heat of the
ox caused extensive abrasion
of the skin below which
was continually healing
and getting ill ^ made new again
To this disagreeable was
added now the chafing
of my projecting bones
on my the hard bed -

Chester On Friday we came
to a village of civil people
on the banks of the Loajima
itself - and we were wet
all day in consequence
of crossing it after starting
The bridges on it & another
stream we crossed at
midday were submerged
breast deep at this time
with as I we have always
found as yet, ^ a flood of perfectly
clear water - On crossing
the latter we were met by
a hostile party who refused
us farther passage, I ordered
my men to proceed in
the same direction we had
been pursuing, but our
463
enemies spread themselves
out in front of us with
loud cries - Our numbers
were about equal to theirs
this time so I moved on
58 at the head of my men - Some
ran off to other villages
others ran back to their
own ^ village on pretence of getting
ammunition - others called
out that all traders came
to them and we must
do ^ the same - so too As As theesethese people
had having ^ had plenty of iron headed
arrows as well as
and some ^ guns, as soon as we
when we ^ came to the edge of the
forest I ordered my men
to put our luggage in our
a central centre and if
our enemies did not fire
incut down some young
trees and make a screen
as quickly as possible
and do nothing to them
except in case of actual
attack - I then dismounted
and advanced a little towards
our principal opponent
shewedshowed him how easily
I could kill him but
pointed upwards saying
I fear God - He did
the same placing his
hand on his heart and
464
pointing upwards but added
and saying - I fear to kill
but come to our village
Come - Do come - At this
juncture the old headman
59 Ionga Panza a venerable
negro came up and I
invited him and all
to be seated that we might
talk the matter over
Ionga Panza soon let us
know that he felt thought
himself very ill treated
in being passed by - As
most accidents skirmishes
arise from misunderstanding
This might have been
a serious one for like
all tribes near the
Portuguese settlements they
people here imagined that
they had a right to demand
payment from every
one who passes through
the country and now
though Ionga Panza was
certainly no match for
my men yet they were
determine not to forego
their rights b without a
struggle - I removed with
my men to the vicinity
of the village - thankful
that no accident had as yet
465
brought us into actual collision

The reason why the
people have imbibed the
the idea so strongly that
60 they have a right to demand
payment for leave to
pass through the country
is probably this - They have
seen no traders except
those either engaged in
purchasing slaves or
who have slaves in their
employment - These slave
traders have always been
very much at the mercy of
their the chiefs through whose
country they have passed
for if they afforded a ready
asylum for the runaway
slaves - the trader might be
deserted at any moment
and left a complete wreck
They are thus obliged to curry
favour with the chiefs
so as to gain a safe con-
-duct from them - as well
so induce them to part
with their people The same
system is adopted to
induce the chiefs
to part with their people
which all feel to be the
real source of their
importance in the country
466
and also that on their return
with chains of slaves it is
so easy for a chief who
might be so disposed to
als take away a chain
61 containing eight or
ten slaves unresisting
slaves that the slave
merchant is fain to
give any amount of
presents in order
to the good will of
the chief - The Independentindependent
chiefs not knowing
much why their favour
is so eagerly sought
become excessively
proud and supercilious
in their demands and
look upon white men
aswith the greatest contempt
To such lengths did
they ^ the Bangala
a tribe near
to which
we had now
approached proceed, a few years
ago in the valley that
they compelled the
Portuguese traders to
pay for water wood
and even grass and
every possible pretext
invented as areasons for
fines - And these were
patiently submitted to
so long as the slave trade
continued to flourish
467
We had unconsciously come
in contact with a system
which iswas quite unknown
in the sSouth th country from
which my men had come
An English trader may hear
there hear ^ a demand for payment
62 of guides but never
so far as I am aware
is he asked for to pay for
leave to pass through the
country - The idea does
not seem to have
entered the native mind
except from slave traders
for the aborigines all
acknowledge that the
untilled land not
needed for pasturage
belongs to God alone
and no harm is done
by people passing through
it - I rather believe that
whenever the slave trade
has not ^ penetrated penetrated the
visits by strangers are
really esteemed a privilege -
Goodby

The village of the old
Ionga Panza is small
and embowered in lofty
evergreen trees which were
hung aroungaround with fine
festoons of creepers
468
He sent us food immediately
and soon afterwards a goat
which was considered
a handsome gift there being
but few domestic animals
here though the country
is well adapted for
63 them - I suspect this
like the country of Shinte
and Katéma must
have been a Tsetse district
and but recently rendered
capable of supporting
domestic animals besides
the goats by the destruction
of the game through the
extensive introduction
of fire arms - The ignorance
of the P We might have
been equally ignorant
of the existence of this
insect plague as the
Portuguese had it not
been for the numerous
migrations of pastoral
tribes which took
place in the South
in consequence of
Zulu irruptions

During these exciting
scenes I always forgot
my fevers but a terrible
sense of sinking came
back with the establishment
of safth safety - The same
469
demand for payment for
leave to pass was made
on the 20th by old Ionga Panza
as by the other Chiboque
I offered the shell presented
by old Shinte but Ionga
Panza said he was
64 too old for ornaments
We might have succeeded
very well with him for
he was by no means
unreasonable and had but
a very small village of
supporters - But our
two guides from
Kangenke complicated
our difficulties by
sending for a body
of Bangala traders with
a view to force us
to sell the tusks of Sekeletu
and pay them with the
proceeds price - We proffered
to pay them handsomely
if they would perform
their promise of guiding
Cassangé us to the Cassange but
they knew no more of
the paths than we did
and my men had paid
them repeatedly and
tried to get rid of them
but could not - They now
joined with our enemies
470
and so did the traders, Two
guns ^ & some beads belonging to the latter
were placed in standing
in our encampment
and one of the guides
seized them and ran off
65 As my men knew
that we should be
called upon to replace
them they gave chase
and as the guides
saw they that they
would be caught they
threw down the guns & directed their flight to
the village - and rushed
into the a hut - The door
way is not much higher
than that of a dog's
kennel one of the
guides was reached
by one of my men
as he was in the
act of stooping to get
in and a cut inflicted
on a projecting part
of the body which
would have made
any one in that posture
wince - The guns were
restored but not the
the beads were lost
in the flight - All the I had
remaining ^ of my stock of beads could not
replace them those lost
and though we explained
471
that we had no part in the
guilt of the act they replied
that we had brought the
thieves into the country - And
these were the Bangala
66 who had been accustomed
to plague the Portuguese
in the most vexatious
way - As we were striving
to get a pathway through
the country and felt
anxious that no crime
whatever should be laid
to our charge we tried the
most conciliatory plans
here though we were not
as in the other instances
likely to be over powered
by numbers - We offered
Robinson My men offered all their
ornaments and I offered
all my beads & shirts
but though we had come
to the village against our
will - the guides had
followed us against
our will and sent
for the Bangala traders
without our knowledge
or consent - yet matters
could not be arranged
without our giving an
ox and one of our
tusks - We were all
472
becoming disheartened and
could not wonder that
native expeditions from
the Interior to the coast
67 had generally failed to
reach their destinations
On My people were now
so much discouraged
that some proposed to
return home This distressed
me exceedingly The prospect
of being obliged to return
when just on the
threshold of the Portuguese
settlements distressed me
exceedingly - and after
using all my powers
of persuasion declared
to them that if they returned
I would go on alone
and went in my little
tent with the mind soul oppressed
yet directed to Him who
hears the sighing of the
soul - and was followed
by the head of Mohorisi
saying "we will
never leave you - Do
not be disheartened - W
Where everWherever you lead we
will follow - Our remarks
were only made only on
account of the injustice
of these people" - Others
followed and in the
473
with the most artless simplicity
68 of manner told me to be
comforted. They were all
my children - They knew
no one but Sekeletu
and me - and they would
die for me - They had
not fought because
I did not wish it They had just
spoken
in the bitterness
of their spirit
& when feeling
that they could
do nothing, - But
if these enemies begin
you will see what we
can do" - I had heard
objection made by the Chiboque to one
one of the oxen we offered to
the Chiboque
refused because ithe
had lost part of his
tail - as they thought
the tail
had been cut
off and
witchcraft
medicine
inserted We now slaughtered
another ox that wasthe spectacle
might not be seen
of the owners of cattle
fasting while the
Chiboque were feasting -
and some mirth was
excited by my proposing
to raise a similar
objection to all the
oxen we ^ still had ^ still remaining
in our possession
The remaining four soon
presented a singular loss
shortness of their caudal extremities
and though no one
ever asked whether
they had medicine in
the stumps or no - we
were no more troubled
474
by the demand for any ox!

24th Friday Ionga PanzasIonga Panza's sons
69 consen agreed to act as
guides into the territory
of the Portuguese if I
would give them the
coveted shell. I was
strongly averse to this
and especially to give
it before-handbeforehand but
I yielded to the entreaty of
my people to appear
as if shewingshowing confidence
in the sons - They
urged that they wished
to leave the shell with
their wives as a sort
of payment for enduring
their absence so long
Having delivered the
precious shell we
went to the WWest & by N-North to
Chikapa the river Chikapa which
here (Lat-Latitude 10° 22' S)outh) is forty or fifty
yards wide and at
present was deep - It was
seen flowing over a
rocky ^ broken cataract with
great noise about
half a mile above
our ford - We were
ferried over in a canoe
made out of a single
peiece of bark and
475
70 sewed together at the ends
and andhaving sticks placed
in it at different parts
to act as ribs - The
word Chikapa means
bark or skin and as this
is the only river win
which we saw this
kind of canoe used
and we heard that
this this stream dries
is so low
during most
of the year up so far in the
dry seasonas to be
feas easily fordable
it probably derives
its name from the
use made of the
bark canoes when
it is in flood - We now
felt the loss of our pontoon
for the people to whom
the canoe belonged made
us pay once when
we began to cross - then
when half of us waere
over and again when
all were over but
my principal man
Pitsané any Pitsané and myself
LoyankaéLoyanké LoyankaeLoyanke took off his
cloth and paid my
passage with it - The
Makololo always ferried
their visitors over ^ rivers without
